appbar.modal: Are you sure you want to leave the current analysis?

analysis.interrupted: Analysis {screen} was interrupted by page refresh and will be resumed

welcomePage.alertEnterRepo: Please enter a repository link before starting!
welcomePage.modal: Are you sure you want to abort the repository download?
welcomePage.invalidRepoUrl: Invalid repository URL. Use GitHub or GitLab URL.

errors.requestTimeout: The request took too long to complete

rightPanel.noSelection: Select a file or directory to view details

hotspots.info: Files suspected of being system hotspots. Refactoring is recommended.

code-age.info: Lists recently modified files and shows the number of days that have passed since they were last modified, relative to the end date of the analyzed period.

filesCoupling.info1: Files that are frequently modified together with others. This helps detect dependencies in the code.
filesCoupling.info2: Files most frequently co-occurring in the same commits as the selected file. Displayed values: number of shared commits and their share in the selected file's commits.

abandoned-code.info1: Files that were co-created by inactive authors and their abandonment percentage.
abandoned-code.info2: Developers who have not committed a change to the repository in the last 6 months and the number of files they have co-authored.

knowledge-risks.info1: The authorship distribution category of a file, determined by the number and activity of its co-authors.
knowledge-risks.info2: Developers contributing to the file and the percentage of historical lines they contributed.

lead-developers.info: The lead authors of files in the repository and the number of files for which they are the primary author.

file-extensions.info: File types present in the repository. Some extensions are skipped during analysis. The value '-' refers to files that have been analyzed but have an unknown extension.

metrics.name: Name
metrics.leadAuthorInfo: Author of the largest total number of lines in the history of a file.
metrics.totalLinesAddedInfo: Total number of lines written in the file history.
metrics.activeAuthorsInfo: Persons who has made a change in the repository in the last 6 months.
metrics.knowledgeRiskInfo: The authorship distribution category of a file, determined by the number and activity of its co-authors (ABD - abandoned, SOW - single owner, BAL - balanced, DIF - diffused, UNK - unknown).
metrics.knowledgeLossInfo: The percentage of the file's total historical lines that come from inactive authors.
metrics.bugsInfo: Potential causes of failure, e.g. possible Null Pointer Exception.
metrics.vulnerabilitiesInfo: Detected vulnerabilities related to CVE code.
metrics.codeSmellsInfo: Problems that make the code difficult to maintain but do not cause compilation errors.
metrics.complexityInfo: A measure of how many independent logical paths there are in the code.
metrics.dateInfo: Status as of the end of the analyzed period.

description.title: Introduction
description.p1: In the software development industry, especially within organizations working on large, long-term projects, managing technical debt and maintaining code quality play a crucial role. As code repositories grow — often spanning thousands of files and hundreds of thousands of lines of code — and as team composition changes over time, identifying areas that require refactoring becomes increasingly difficult. Current code quality management processes often rely on code reviews and reactive problem-solving, addressing issues only after defects appear. In recent years, however, behavioral code analysis methods have gained popularity, enhancing traditional static analysis with data from version control systems, such as change history and team collaboration patterns. Combining structural and behavioral perspectives enables faster detection of risky code areas before they evolve into more serious issues.
description.p2: Manual identification of code that requires attention can be time-consuming and inefficient, often leading to the omission of critical areas. Refactoring decisions are frequently made intuitively, without access to data that integrates both technical and organizational aspects of the project. Additional challenges include limited visibility into how knowledge is distributed within the team and how different modules depend on each other. Inefficient planning of maintenance activities and poor issue prediction lead to higher project maintenance costs. Therefore, there is a strong need for effective visualization of both technical and organizational data, enabling quick understanding of system structure and supporting decision-making regarding refactoring priorities.
description.p3: Existing tools, such as CodeScene, offer advanced capabilities for detecting areas that require attention by combining static and behavioral code analysis. However, their complex interfaces are not always intuitive, particularly for less experienced users who may feel overwhelmed by the volume of data and visualizations. Furthermore, the transparency of the metrics used and the methods for calculating them are not always clearly presented, which can make it even more difficult to interpret the results accurately.
